ai-ud3.2:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud3.2:1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Nanda, the Buddha said this to many mendicants:
ai-ud3.2:1.5_0: I am unable to keep up the spiritual life. I shall resign the training and return to a lesser life.”
ai-ud3.2:2.1_0: Then a certain monk went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud3.2:2.3_0: “Sir, Venerable Nanda—who is the Buddha’s brother, his mother’s sister out of
ai-ud3.2:2.4_0: you are unable to keep up the spiritual life; that you shall resign the training and return to a lesser life?”
ai-ud3.2:3.1_0: Then the Fortunate One addressed a certain monk, (saying):
ai-ud3.2:3.2_0: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Nanda that
ai-ud3.2:3.4_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Nanda:
ai-ud3.2:4.1_0: “Yes, reverend,” Nanda replied. He went to the Buddha, and told him.
ai-ud3.2:4.2_0: He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
ai-ud3.2:5.1_0: “Is it really true, Nanda, that you informed several mendicants that
ai-ud3.2:5.2_0: you are unable to keep up the spiritual life; that you shall resign the training and return to a lesser life?”
ai-ud3.2:6.1_0: “But why are you so dissatisfied with the spiritual life?”
ai-ud3.2:6.2_0: “As I left my house, sir, the finest lady of the Sakyan land, her hair half-combed, glanced at me and said,
ai-ud3.2:6.4_0: Recalling that, I am dissatisfied and shall resign the training.”
ai-ud3.2:7.1_0: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the Thirty-Three.
ai-ud3.2:7.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-ud3.2:7.4_0: and disappeared from Jeta’s Wood, and reappear amongst the Tāvatiṁsa devas.
ai-ud3.2:8.1_0: Now at that time five hundred celestial dove-footed nymphs were ready.
ai-ud3.2:8.2_0: Then the Buddha said to Nanda,
ai-ud3.2:8.3_0: “Nanda, do you see these five hundred dove-footed nymphs?”
ai-ud3.2:9.1_0: “What do you think, Nanda, are more than these five hundred sights?”
ai-ud3.2:9.2_0: “Compared to these five hundred dove-footed nymphs, the finest lady of the Sakyan land is like a deformed monkey with its ears and nose cut off.
ai-ud3.2:9.3_0: In the same way, reverend Sir, the finest lady in the land of the five lower fetters counterparts, indivisions, not even a finger-snap.
ai-ud3.2:9.4_0: These five hundred celestial dove-footed nymphs and more are the more.”
ai-ud3.2:10.2_0: and I am dying with five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”
ai-ud3.2:10.3_0: “If, sir, you guarantee me five hundred dove-footed nymphs, I shall happily lead the spiritual life under the Buddha.”
ai-ud3.2:11.1_0: Then the Buddha took Nanda by the arm and, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Jeta’s Grove and reappeared among the gods of the Thirty-Three.
ai-ud3.2:11.2_0: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, they vanished from the bank of the river Vaggumudā, and reappeared in the presence of the Buddha in the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-ud3.2:11.4_0: did he vanish from amongst the Tāvatiṁsa devas, and reappear in Jeta’s Wood.
ai-ud3.2:12.2_0: “Venerable Nanda, it seems the Buddha’s brother, his mother’s sister’s son,
ai-ud3.2:12.3_0: And it seems that the Buddha guaranteed him five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”
ai-ud3.2:13.1_0: Monks who were his friends accused him of being a hireling and a lackey,
ai-ud3.2:13.2_0: “It seems Nanda is a hireling, it seems he is a lackey: he leads the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.
ai-ud3.2:13.3_0: And it seems that the Buddha guaranteed him five hundred dove-footed nymphs.”
ai-ud3.2:14.1_0: Being troubled by the mendicants, Venerable Nandaka, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.
ai-ud3.2:14.2_0: And in this very life, he soon realized with his own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.
ai-ud3.2:14.3_0: for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.
ai-ud3.2:14.4_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-ud3.2:14.5_0: And venerable Nanda became another of the Worthy Ones.
ai-ud3.2:15.1_0: Then, late at night, a glorious deity, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha. Thinking,
ai-ud3.2:15.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-ud3.2:15.2_0: While standing on one side that god said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud3.2:15.3_0: “Sir, Venerable Nanda—who is both the Buddha’s half-brother and maternal cousin—has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. He lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
ai-ud3.2:15.4_0: And the knowledge also came to the Buddha:
ai-ud3.2:15.5_0: “Nanda, you had realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom. And you live having realized it with your own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
ai-ud3.2:16.1_0: Then, when the night had passed, venerable Nanda went to the Fortunate One,
ai-ud3.2:16.2_0: While sat on one side venerable Nanda said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud3.2:16.3_0: “Sir, as the Buddha guaranteed me five hundred dove-footed nymphs, I shall enjoy the Buddha.”
ai-ud3.2:16.4_0: “Nanda, I comprehended your mind and knew that
ai-ud3.2:16.5_0: you had realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom.
ai-ud3.2:16.7_0: ‘Sir, Venerable Nanda—who is both the Buddha’s half-brother and maternal cousin—has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. He lives having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
ai-ud3.2:16.8_0: As soon as your mind was freed from defilements by not grasping, I was released from that promise.”
ai-ud3.2:17.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud3.2:18.1_0: “The mendicant who has crossed over the bog,
ai-ud3.2:18.2_0: who has crushed the thorns of sensuality,
ai-ud3.2:18.3_0: who has reached the end of delusion,
ai-ud3.2:18.4_0: trembles not at pleasure and pain.”
